title: Low-energy Spectra of Nobelium Isotopes Skyrme Random-Phase-approximation Analysis.pdf
abstract: Nesterenko 1,2, M.A. Mardyban 1,2, A. Repko 3, R.V. Jolos1,2, and P.-G. Reinhard 4 1 Laboratory of Theoretical Physics, Joint Institute for Nuclear Research. 141980, Dubna, Moscow region, Russia 2 Dubna State University. 141982, Dubna, Moscow region, Russia 3 Institute of Physics, Slovak Academy of Sciences, 84511 Bratislava, Slovakia and 4 Institute for Theoretical Physics II, University of Erlangen, D-91058, Erlangen, Germany (Dated: February 14, 2025) Low-energy spectra in the isotopic chain 250−262No are systematically investigated within the fully self-consistent Quasiparticle Random-Phase-Approximation (QRPA) using Skyrme forces SLy6, SkM* and SVbas. QRPA states of multipolarity λµ=20, 22, 30, 31, 32, 33, 43, 44 and 98 are considered. The main attention is paid to isotopes 252No and 254No, for which the most extensive experimental spectroscopic information is available. In these two nuclei, a reasonable description of Kπ = 8−, 2−and 3+ isomers is obtained with the force SLy6. The disputed 8−isomer in 254No is assigned as neutron two-quasiparticle conﬁguration nn[734 ↑, 613 ↑]. At the energies 1.2 - 1.4 MeV, the 2qp K-isomers 4−, 7−in 252No and 4−, 6−, 7−in 254No are predicted. In 254No, the Kπ = 3+ isomer should be accompanied by the nearby Kπ = 4+ counterpart. It is shown that, in the chain 250−262No, some features of 252No and 254No exhibit essential irregularities caused by a shell gap in the neutron single-particle spectrum and corresponding breakdown of the neutron pairing. In particular, low-energy pairing-vibrational Kπ = 0+ states in 252,254No are predicted. I. INTRODUCTION Spectroscopy of transfermium nuclei (Pu, Cm, Cf, Fm, No) is presently of a large interest, see reviews [1–3] and references therein. These nuclei provide a valuable infor- mation on the single-particle spectra and pairing in heavy nuclei, which in turn can be useful for understanding the features of neighbouring superheavy nuclei. Though experimental spectroscopic information for transfermium nuclei is permanently increasing (see early [4–8] and re- cent [9–11] experimental studies), it still remains rather scarce. Among transfermium nuclei, nobelium isotopes have, perhaps, the most extensive experimental spectro- scopic data [1, 2, 12]. Among nobelium isotopes, 252No and 254No are most investigated[1, 2]. In these two nuclei, long ground-state rotational bands (up to Iπ = 20+ in 252No and Iπ = 24+ in 254No) are observed. Already for two decades, two- quasiparticle (2qp) Kπ = 8−isomers (at 1.254 MeV in 252No and 1.296 MeV in 254No) are scrutinized by both experiment and theory. Some low-energy rotational bands with band heads Kπ = 2−at 0.929 MeV in 252No and Kπ = 3+ at 0.987 MeV in 254No are found. Quite recently nonrotational states Kπ = 4+ (1.203 MeV) and 0+ (0.888 MeV) in 254No were tentatively observed [10]. The 0+ state was treated as a result of the coupling be- tween ”normal” deformed and superdeformed shapes. While the experimental information on nobelium iso- topes is generally poor, there is already a lot of the- oretical studies and predictions. The quadrupole mo- ments and corresponding quadrupole deformations were estimated, see e.g. [13–16]. Single-particle (s-p) spec- tra, moments of inertia and pairing eﬀects were system- atically explored [16] using diﬀerent density functional theories (DFT): relativistic covariant [17], Skyrme [18] and Gogny [19]. Various multipole low-energy two- quasiparticle (2qp) excitations were considered in self- consistent calculations with Gogny force [15]. A thorough investigation of s-p spectra, deformations, pairing and α-decay features in nobelium isotopes was recently per- formed within the symmetry-unrestricted nonrelativis- tic mean-ﬁeld model employing a shell correction anal- ysis [20]. Further, long rotational bands in 252,254No were in- vestigated within cranked shell model [21–23], Skyrme- Hartree-Fock-Bogoliubov and Lipkin-Nogami methods [24], and interacting-boson model (IBM) [25]. The relation between the lowest 1−states and reﬂec- tion asymmetry in nobelium isotopes was studied [26]. Within the cluster model, the alternative parity bands based on the ground 0+ and vibrational 1−states were predicted as a consequence of the reﬂection asymme- try [27]. The scissor mode was measured [28] and an- alyzed within the Wigner Function Method [29]. K-isomers in 252,254No were also widely explored, see e.g. [4–6, 10, 11, 22, 23, 30–34]. In particu- lar, two-quasiparticle K-isomers 8−, 2−and 3+ were considered using Woods-Saxon potential and schematic QRPA approach [6, 30, 31]. Within the cranking shell model (Nilsson potential with hexadecapole deformation) + pairing treated with the particle-number projection (CSM+PNP), a nice description of the energy of 8−- isomer in 254No was obtained [33]. In the combined ex- periment + theory (Woods-Saxon potential + pairing) study [6], the complete decay scheme for isomers 8−was suggested (though being further disputed in a later ex- periment [10, 11]). Using the two-center shell model, α- decays relevant for the K-isomers were explored [32]. In pairing blocking and QRPA calculations [31], low-energy states with Kπ = 0−, 1−, 2−, 3+, 8−were considered; for 2−, 3+, 8−states in 252,254No, a good agreement with the experimental data was obtained.
